reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is in my opinion the epitome of a true 4 out of 10.

It isnt terrible, but also isnt good.

Basically, you are a British soldier investigating what happened to an armoured column of your armed forces mates in Burma circa WW2. Now, there is a lot wrong with the idea that one man is going to investigate the disappearance of hundreds, but whatever....keep it simple. It's all good.

Add to that the basic story arc of a Buddhist apocalypse, and the comical aspects of this story reach their crescendo.

So, what about the gameplay? Well, you basically wander around with a pistol, killing the occasional zombie and reading the occasional note...when you can actually click on the note. Often, the game doesnt register your proximity to said notes, and so you cant click on them. I did find an end around by simply jumping on top of whatever surface the notes were on and reading them through my pistol's ironsights, lol.

Speaking of the pistol you cling to in this game....you pass by a plethora of other weapons, including grenades, assault rifles, etc...but your soldier doesnt seem to think they are good weapons, and so you are never able to actually pick them up or use them. They are simply part of the backdrop.

The graphics themselves are what you would expect from the vanilla Unity engine. Somewhat washed out and basic. I actually dont have a problem with that, and overall, I did think it looked fine for what it was going for.

I also thought the level design was decent. It's obviously a linear experience, but frankly, given the sparse nature of the game and the relative lack of encounters, this works fine. It is designed to build tension, and does a decent job of this overall, although you do come to realize quickly that you really dont need to be too worried about what might be around the next corner since typically there wont be anything, lol.

The audio is fairly typical of these types of games. Sort of ominous sounding, with spikes in volume to try and scare you or make you more tense at the least. This would be more effective if there wasnt such a lack of enemies. Still, decent for what has become stock audio files (from what I can tell since I've heard the same music in other Unity engine games).

So...enemies. There are basically three types...your standard weak zombie, your soldier zombies that are essentially a bit more bullet resistant, and the fire spawned zombies (at least that is what I am calling them), which can easily soak up a clip or two of bullets before they die, depending on how close you are to them. They all simply rush you, so you will generally have plenty of time to drop them before they get near you.

Now, your pistol is actually pretty easy to aim, and that was another positive aspect of the game. Pretty seamless, with auto reload if you drain your clip (or enter a new section of the map) or manual if you discharged a couple bullets and want to be ready for the next encounter. Bullets are fairly sparse up until a specific section, but you always have just enough to deal with the 1-3 enemies you will encounter every couple of sections/levels.

Interestingly enough, there is a section which basically amounts to the boss battle, and in that lone section, it goes from a zombie here, a zombie there to an actual horde. I thought that was actually a challenging battle. You dont actually have to win. You simply have to survive for a certain amount of time. That was actually kind of cool IMO.

Anyway, I will play Act 3 when it is released, and I dont regret playing this game at all, but it doesnt change the fact that, at least in my opinion, this is exactly what a 4 out of 10 game looks and plays like. It is currently priced at $5 USD. I wouldnt pay that much for it. For $2 or less though, I feel it would be worth a look. Still, based on a 4 out of 10, I give this game a thumbs down with the caveat that, for the right price, or as a bundle game, it is worth at least checking out.

Also, this is k/m only folks.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game was very hard for me to place. There are many good aspects in it, including an interesting story line, and a  great horror ambiance (for the most part). However, there are still many things that should be fixed. First of all, the sound balance. In the beginning of the game, the wind is way to prominent, making it hard to hear anything else, including the horror atmosphere and the main characters voice. Furthermore, I'm not a big fan of the cut scene transitions. The first one caught me off guard. The computer takes control of your movement and floats you to the next area. This breaks the illusion of being in the game. It would be much better to be able to transition between places yourself, which would also keep me more absorbed in it. The game is still very interesting, but has some aspects that should be fixed. But since this is only in the beta, I'm sure that there are going to be many updates improving it, and I can't wait for them to come out. Still, this is a very enjoyable game, and for the price it's definitely worth buying. Below I posted my walk through of act 1, if you want to see it.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mgKuQ9cJ6qk&list=PLKMxTuqznyPPkgaE6aqdCot48LWE2GXsv&index=1

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Please Note I am currently on ACT II

At first glance the graphics aren't amazing. Yet the suspence and horror is awesome. There are many think fast moments and pop ups that catch you off guard. When I was playing I flet parnoid looking behind me and taking corners slowly.The story is relatively simple but keeps the player hooked and makes him/her want to play, dive deeper into the game.


The animations are a bit choppy and the textures could use some reworking. I would like to see more weapons other than the Browning High-Power (Pistol), maybe the Lee-enfield or a Sten.  I would love to see co-op added to this game, would make even more enjoyable. Some ragdoll affects would be nice and would make killing enemies more statsfying.

Overall Opinion:

For the price this game is awesome! I love the WW2 setting it fits the game very well. If you can look past the graphics and animations your will find enjoyment in this game. I am looking forward to the patchs and updates that will be coming soon. A few improvements later this game could be a horror masterpiece! GET IT!

The Bad

Early Access Review

This game is just a huge mess. Most of the 90s/early 2000 games gave you a small free roam place to run around, this game, takes away that by placing invisible walls and telling you that you have to go this way! Going up stairs is a nightmare. If you wanna climb stairs better jump all the way up the stairs. Dont let me get started about ammo. each time you pick up ammo and you reach a new area, you lose all of your ammo. I passed 4 weapons from melee to rifles /machine guns and couldnt even pick them up.  I found myself questioning how did the devs even try to come up with the story when some of the tank objects/deaths just dont make since. Ex: 2 tanks in the middle of a bunker. NO WAY ON EARTH THESE TANKS DROVE OVER THE BUNKER. IT JUST DOESNT ADD UP. ANOTHER ONE: A GROUP OF 6 MEN DEAD FROM A ZOMBIE ATTACK.. 1 was on a flak.... LIKE REALLY??

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe Falling Sun isn't a bad game at all. In fact I actually enjoyed a lot of aspects about it. It's not Unity engine fodder by any means, and utilizes the engine quite well. There is a decent story set in WW2 thats focused on the Japenese side, which is new and refreshing, and it has high potential for it being early access. However, there are quite a few issues that come with it. While the ambience is pretty good, most monsters roar loudly wherever theyre placed in the map, and even louder when they die. Killing them in mass results in an ear ache. The campaign seems to have unlimited ammo for the only weapon you have, which is a pistol. To counteract that though, you die in one hit, and the monsters are faster than you are. In the horror aspect, there was a handful of moments i felt tension. Walking through a jungle filled area not being able to see what was ahead was a bit nerveracking, especially since you die in one hit. And towards the end there was a holdout where the amount that rushed at you was a little intense. The cutscenes seemed to not work for me, it just  stayed in one frame where there was only audio so i had no idea what the hell was going on. I understand there will be more acts but the campaign was only 20 minutes or so. But a fun 20 minutes. Decent voice acting, and the gameplay runs quite smoothly.  As for the survival mode, a lot can be tweaked. While fun, theres only 3 maps. 2 where you can barely move from one position and one where its a very small area, but definitely the most enjoyable to me.  The survival aspect has limited ammo, keep moving to ammo pickups to survive. the rush of the enemies does add tension, but like i said, the ear ache is real. and the amount of corpses to see is obnoxious. While fun to stand amongst the corpses and bathe in the blood of your enemies, the lag is present. not gamebreaking, but annoying. However it is addicting for me to go back and try to beat my high score. all in all i have high hopes for this game, being in early access, theres room for more improvement, possibly more weapons, story development, more survival maps, and an indie title id like to hold in high regard.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I will say this. For a first try from a new studio this isnt bad. However, there is much better.

I didnt like the overly straight line format of this game. There was 0 room for explanation when you just goin in a straght line. No explorations, nothing bigger than two rooms or so and some halls. I woudlnt count level design as even an aspect. Maybe it will change later? I have no idea.

Sounds are fairly OK...a bit loud where it comes to Zombies, but the rest of the sounds were fairly nice.

Models are very low poly. Its very much like Halflife 1 with some Halflife 2 in there. I didnt find it a very modern or attractive game. There isnt much to look at.

Walking can get you stuck on ground clutter and you will find yoruself avoiding an open area because of physics with garbage on the ground forcing you to sidestep.

*Shrugs* I have like 300 FPS. I know what Im saying here.

Not yet. Maybe never. It can only get better. Right?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Based on the comments, I was preparing my second keyboard and the computer key removal kit. Bu I was quite pleasantly surprised. The game runs well, even on my piece of {Grawlix} laptop. The game goes from note to note, allowing the protagonist, (who, unlike me, doesn't {Grawlix} himself when the phone rings) to piece together the history leading up to the destruction of the armored bat(t?)allion in question. Although you don't pick up the hundreds of guns you see next to corpses, ammo is given according to need, and extra is found hidden around the areas. The game could do with Subtitles at points (the accents sound like cuneiform in midair at times), the audio is well done. Perhaps slightly more dialogue, or maybe an NPC would allow the story to flow more easily, but it is easily picked up through atmospheric qeues. For an  EARLY ACCESS  game, it is quite good.
8/9.162

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Falling Sun Review

Hello, first of all, i'd like to thank everyone that is reading this review, because it is my first.


Well, let's start


The Falling Sun, is a first person horror game set in post-WW2 Burma. The Japanese have withdrawn after the Allied victory and British forces regain control of the region, however when a small armoured column goes silent, a young lieutenant is sent on one last mission to find out what happened. Upon his arrival he is faced with horrors beyond that of the World War, will you be able to overcome them?

The game uses the unity engine,  it does has a story and the best part , There are no paid DLCs!
You guys should be thinking about what happens when the WW2 is finally over... well, it basically stops? not in this game!
There are a lot of Updates coming with new Acts, new bug fixes, innovations, and YOU, my friend, who bought the game, won't need to pay anything for that!, yes, you read it right, i repeat, there are no paid DLCs
The story take place in japan, so basically, what can we expect? nuclear bombs? Zombies? Yes, expect everything, because this game has potential
About the price, i think it's worth, since the game is in early access and still updating, i'd say, it's worth!
To conclude this, i'm gonna say what i think about the game, in my opinion:
The game has everything to be good, just need that magic touch from developers and more ideas, zombies in a WW2 Game? hell yeah, i'd love to see someone being devoured over and over again.... :P

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Falling Sun is a new early access indie horror title coming to Steam 4/7/2015!

I got a chance to play through the first Act of this game and it uses the Unity engine effectively.

So the game takes place in Burma, during WWII, you seem to be stuck in the midst of some crazy Nazi occultist ♥♥♥♥. You play in first person as you're trying to figure out the usual for a horror game. The who, what, and why. I know its some Nazi stuff, with weird alien or magic going on. I'm not to sure.

What I did find out, however, was that this game does a great job of making you feel on edge. The interiors are tight and foggy, with many corridors and creepy sounds. The outside is dense forest and weird ruins. The creatures you face are still unknown to me, they seem to be skinless people? Monsters? Naked monster Nazis? No quite sure but the sound they make (which is the same sound everytime =(  scare the hell out of me).

They've done a great job with the ambiance and from what I can tell the game is pacing very well. I do have some Nazi bones to pick though. The load times are very poor right now. The first act is split into 6 separate parts and you hit these points where the cut to the next scene is abrupt and jarring. I'd love to see the acts as one continuous level.

Other then that I see this game turning out to be a scary adventure with an interesting story and setting. So keep your eyes on this one.

Here's my First Look of Act 1!

https://youtu.be/vnjp06eeD64


You can pick up The Falling Sun in Early Access on Steam 4/7/2015 for $5!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

right I brought this game just to try it out, it looked interesting and I wanted to see if it lived up to my expectations, did it well....

CONS
-First of all im gonna start with the cons of this game as there are a lot of this game.
-This game is short, I brought it today and completed it in 31 minuits, I expected the game to be longer.
-The shooting seems a little off, sometimes It didnt feel as if the bullet was hitting the enemy where i wanted, not sure if it was just me or if its meant to be that way.
-sometimes when climbing stairs or going through the levels, I would sometimes find myself getting stuck on something, it didnt happen a lot but its something that needs to be addressed.
-The voice acting sounds a little rushed and it doesnt show much emotion, I mean if i was stuck in a Burmese jungle, with Japanese/Burmese zombies running around, sounds of Arisaki bolt action rifles being fired. I would be sounding scared and you know wanting to get the hell out of there.
-you see Arisaka rifles on the ground, or machine guns planted down on the ground but you can never pick them up and you are just reduced to being a soldier with a pistol.
-after reaching a cutscene your ammo is reduced back default 8 bullets a lot of the time, even if you had more to begin with.

Pros
-First and best thing the sounds quality in this game are top notch, I had to turn it down because it was too loud and it was still loud enough to create a good atmosphere.
-The plot even though never really explained and only found through soldier and engineer reports in the game, deffinitly fits into the war like scenario. I found the story interesting and even if its small, the background story is a lot more interesting then other shooters I have seen.
-As easy as it is to kill an enemy dam when they hit they do some damage, which could add to the challenge of the game, but at the same time they never really get a chance to hit you. so this is really a good and bad situation.
-The game has errors and such and it knows it, I am happy that the game doesnt try to sugar coat what it is or what its trying to achieve.

This was a little fun game and proberly worth picking up when the developers have fixed alot of the problems with the game, and made it a little better (REMEMBERING THAT THIS GAME IS EARLY ACCESS)
My opinion on the game is 5/10 its a early access game and still has a lot of time to improve itself. I dont really like rating but considering this game has a lot of good things and a lot of bad things. Its all up to you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Written after a second play through following the 1.01 patch.

There is a lot to like about this game. The horror aspect is done really well and for a world war two horror game that's pretty important. It's tense and atmospheric and has jump scares a plenty.
As an early access game, it has tons of potential but it is currently still a little lacking in features (particularly the survival mode). There is a second patch already announced which promises to improve things further and my recomendation is really more to keep an eye on this games development rather than to necessarily buy it now, although for the tiny asking price, you can't really go wrong.

Check out my video for a look at the first two acts (after the patch) and my thoughts on the game generally.
http://youtu.be/xhGbEJAkZ9k

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nLet me explain. The first 15 minutes were absolutely terrifying (once you figured out how to get out of the starting area that is), the atmosphere in the first section made my heart race, and that's coming from someone who doesn't scare easily. That being said, the introduction of the monster for the first time was disappointing. And from that point the game abandoned any semblance of atmosphere. The monster not being particularly scary, the game becomes lackluster from this point on. For just a few other minor points, there's a section in the middle where it's incredibly easy to get lost and another section where theres a long path in both directions and one leads to a dead end, with no indication of where you're supposed to turn. The boss fight is essentially a shoot-em-up stage AND if you fail that you restart the game at a checkpoint WITH ALL THE AMMO YOU HAD FROM THAT FIGHT! (you pick up around 200 bullets in a game that's centred around having limited ammo). On that note, only God knows how the checkpoint system works and if you run out of bullets, you are screwed, there's no way to recover, no meele, no way to get more ammo. The monster just kills you and sends you back to God knows what checkpoint. So why do I reccommend this game? It's cheap and Early Access, there's tremendous potential here and lots of gameplay already. As such, I forgive some of it's flaws

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Falling Sun is a great horror game that plays well off your senses, with a well-detailed world and gameplay mechanics.

It's contantly updated with new content and, for an Early Access Game, I think the developers are doing a fantastic job of listening to the players and implementing changes.

The gameplay is solid, with an easy to master contol system, and simplistic graphics. I think this complements the game well and works in its favour to keep you immersed, it's not there to wow you away in terms of graphics but rather immerse you with gameplay. And it pulls it off well!

Definitely recommended!

Early Access Review

干的好!

Just done the ea version. Surely will have more than just a pistol later but what I want to say is I'd LOVE to have the katana. It's (was) the Japanese front. Love the whole jungle deal in there, rich and thick and it blocks the sight as it should. So far real good enemy distribution thru the levels, i.e. scattered mostly rather than flooding everywhere(except the...), which is a good way to enhance the atmosphere of isolation rather than zed parties. Enemy do have different appearances in campaign levels which is a good thing indeed, very realistc thinking indeed. Too many games with just different 'types' of zeds wearing exactly the same stuffs.

Needs polishing(of course they know). Another thing: arent't ammo crates with a white star and a circle around it supposedly US issue? Yet we see British soldiers lying around. Would be glad if this gets sorted out, even better if this was not even the case.

Thanks for the game. Devs. Look forward to new episodes.

Out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This FPS is painful to play. I didn't really have any context to understand the story, but figured the game would fill me in, but other than scattered notes and a few points of voiced dialogue, I didn't really know what I was doing. The game tries to build suspese, so initially you have a pistol with a flashlight attached, but the flashlight only shines a very narrow beam of light, so I was feeling dizzy and sick on the first level. Once I got through that, things brightened, and the levels opened up a bit, but still felt cramped. Once I got into underbrush, I literally couldn't see anything other than leaves in my face, and had no idea of direction.

The combat I experienced consisted of lurching zombie like things shambling towards me. I would blast them with my pistol, but had no crosshairs or feedback for whether I was hitting them, until they died. The weird thing was that there are dead soliders everywhere, rifles, machine guns, crates of ammo... but I still run around with my pistol and a single clip.

There just wasn't anything fun about the experience of playing this game, and I'm excited to uninstall it.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am retracting my positive review. This game does NOT update and I no longer hear much at all from the developers; I am under the presumption that they have abandoned ship on this title.

It's an alright game still if you're looking for about 30 minutes of time to kill, but don't buy this game with many expectations.
-----------------------
Edit: I did recently come across some bits of information. Firstly, part of the hindered updating may have been the result of one key developer being put in the hospital late October. Secondly, according to an admin post, 'The Falling Sun' is the first legitimate product of most of these developers--so granted, issues are/was to be expected here and there. It is also worth mentioning that the team is busy with alternative jobs (bear in mind, they can't possibly live off of the income they make from The Falling Sun, alone.)

From what I can see, The Falling Sun was their attempt at getting 'off the ground' in the world of game publishing; bad preplanning might have been a severely negative factor here. Could this game bounce back with a miracle update that justifies the long wait? Perhaps, perhaps.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Falling Sun is a horror game taking place in WW2 Burma.

The history enthusiast in me is already getting excited, but should it?

https://youtu.be/zpHRNKqnN7I

Now the game is in early access and even though I gave the game a thumbs up, I strongly suggest not buying it if you don't actually enjoy playing incomplete products. As in giving feedback and possible bug reporting to the dev.

Gameplay wise the game is a basic FPS horror game with little to tell.
You walk around the very linear path given to you and collect notes telling you what is going on in this Japanese military research base.
You also have pistol which you use to dispatch very annoying enemy's, who are extremely loud and kill you in one hit.
Thankfully they are easy to kill as long as you don't let them to startle you too much.

Quite a impossible feat in the survival mode of the game, which is at the moment not that impressive.

(Don't wear headphones for this video of the survival mode)

https://youtu.be/_0vTegChFcI


Unlike many other early access games, this one seems to have at least some promise behind it and isn't completely awful.
And the price isn't bad either.

Apart from the screams that is...
I can still hear them...
Help me...

If you want to take a look at some gameplay of the entire first act of the games campaign, then just look down below for my video of it.

https://youtu.be/zpHRNKqnN7I

And also the... pain inducing video of survival mode... be wary...

https://youtu.be/_0vTegChFcI

reviewText:
Early Access Review

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LC51HQaIxYg
Game: The Falling Sun
Genre: First-person horror
Developer: LonePlanetStudios
Publisher: GrabTheGames
Copy supplied by developer

The Falling Sun is a first-person horror shooter in Early Access developed by LonePlanetStudios and published by GrabTheGames. This review is based on the first release of the game and no update has been made.

STORYThe story takes place in Burma after the end of World War II. You play as a lieutenant who is sent to look for a missing armoured colon. What he is gonna find are failed experiments and mayhem. There are currently two acts to the game, and so far little to nothing is explained and the story feels almost non-existent. Most of the story is told through letters found around the environment, which are poorly written and don't matter that much to the plot.

GRAPHICSThe game does look really good: even though it's made in the Unity engine, there are many video options including antialiasing and refresh rate that goes up to 120 FPS. The game also performs really well. Unfortunately, all the environments are uninspired and boring, there is only one enemy type and there is the most useless flashlight in all of gaming history (it basically only lights your character's hands).

GAMEPLAYThe two acts of the campaign are incredibly short, for a total of 20 minutes of gameplay. There is currently only one firearm, with apparently unlimited ammo. There is also a Survival mode featuring three maps where you have to fend off an unlimited wave of monsters.

CHALLENGEThe game is really, really easy. In the campaign you only meet a handful of monsters: they are usually far away from you because they kill you instantly and they all go down with two shots. In Survival mode you will fail because of the number of corpses that make the game's performance fall really fast.

SOUNDThere are endless loops of loud and annoying background noise, as well as missing sound effects when sprinting. The monsters always start screaming when they spawn, and when playing Survival mode it feels like you are becoming deaf by the second.

REPLAYABILITYThere are no collectibles, no secrets, no achievements and no completion bonuses. The only real reason why you should replay this game is to read the letters scattered around the linear path.

Overall, I can not recommend this game at its current state: it is incredibly short and easy, there is no real reason why you should replay it and even though it is really well optimised, the sound department has to be improved and fixed. I will revisit this game when it comes out of Early Access, because it has really good potential.

Story: 5
Graphics: 7
Gameplay: 4
Challenge: 2
Sound: 3
Replayability: 1

ENJOYMENT: 4
FRUSTRATION: 2
Follow me on Twitter: @nickygra97
Subscribe to my channel
Like on Facebook

Join my Steam group

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(This review is subject to change as THE FALLING SUN progresses through development).

The devs have described the first two (and currently only two) acts of this game as 'finished' which is bad, bad news before you even start poking around the little bugs and glitches that are to be expected with an Early Access title.
My massive problem with THE FALLING SUN is that it feels so overwhelmingly empty. You'll finish two acts in twenty minutes tops and see maybe five admittedly well modelled enemies aside from a wave-based set piece at the latter act's finale. There is nothing to interact with aside from a few scattered memos and one instance where you need to find a key to open a door that can be found about twenty feet away.
For me, THE FALLING SUN isn't atmospheric or cohesively narrated enough to be an effective horror game and lacks every basic mechanic necessary to be a shooter. It cycles through scenery like a holiday snaps slideshow. You die in one hit but so do the enemies.
I'll see how it develops in the next couple of acts and patches. It is, to its credit, a fairly good looking game but aside from that, this is essentially a walking simulator with maybe twenty bullets worth of action to its name.

Check out my abridged playthrough below.
https://youtu.be/ldLml_kEbv4

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Got this game for free luckily. Played it for 41 minutes untill i got stuck into what i assume is the last level since zombies just keep on coming and i don't have enough ammo to fight them off.

If the zombies touch you, you are dead. Instakill zombies wtf. Medkits in the game do not make any sense since what i assume is the only part where you can get damaged is when you have to duck under flames.

The graphics are ugly as one would expect from budget indie horror games on unity engine. Sounds are bad and even in low volume from the mixer the zombie sounds are breaking my eardrums. Note to devs turning the volume of scary sound to the level of a nuclear detonation does not make the game scary. If you are going to play this then i would recommend to mute the whole thing since there really is nothing worth listening to.

Uninstall works so 5/5 for that. Game itself 0/5
